item.title: Research Portfolio
item.description:
Submitted and under review

Submitted and under review Status
“Advanced Practice Registered Nurse Full Practice Authority, Provider Supply, and Health Outcomes: A Border Analysis” with Kihwan Bae (West Virginia University), Conor Norris (West Virginia University), and Edward Timmons (West Virginia University) Under review
“The Pharmacist Will See You Now: Pharmacist Prescriptive Authority and Access to Care in Idaho” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) Under review
“Scope of Practice and Opioid Prescribing Behavior of Nurse Practitioners Serving Medicare Beneficiaries” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) Revision requested
“Do Public Libraries Help Mitigate Crime? Evidence from Kansas City, MO” with Amir Neto (Florida Gulf Coast University) and Jennifer Nowicki (The Pennsylvania State University) Revision requested
“Does Gender Gap in Test Score Exist? Evidence from Administrative Data from Afghanistan” with Ahmad Shah Mobariz (Pittsburg University) Revision requested
“Prescription Opioid Spillovers: Retail Pharmacies Level Analysis” with Collin Hodges (University of Central Arkansas) Working paper
“Impact of Must-access PDMPs on Prescription Opioid Overdose Death Rates” Working paper
“The Interstate Medical Licensure Compact, Physicians’ Mobility, and Nurse Practitioner’s Scope of Practice Law” Working paper
“Industry Regulation Spillover Networks” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) and Juan Tomas Sayago-Gomez (Universidad Icesi) Working paper
“Proximity to the Mental Health Providers in the United States” with Agnitra RoyChoudhury (Auburn University of Montgomery) Working paper
“Heterogeneous Treatment Effects of Medicaid” Working paper
“The Impact of Fracking on the Asset Portfolio Allocation of Local Banking Markets” with Eduardo Minucci (North Carolina A&T State University) Working paper
“Colonial Heritage, Traditional, and Chinese Foreign Direct Investments in Africa: A Dynamic Spatial Interdependence Analysis” with Xiaoli Etienne (University of Idaho) and Mohamed Shabani Kariburyo (The World Bank) Working paper
“Impact of Energy Transition on Energy Burden” with Pinky Thomas Working paper
“A Campagin Worth a Thousand Words in Crowdfunding Descriptions” with Anna Ruboyianes (California State University, San Bernardino) and Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University)
“Individualism and Financial Inclusion” with Nabamitta Dutta (University of Wisconsin - La Crosse) Working paper
“Regional Institutional Quality and Job Creation among Early Startups in the United States” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) Working paper
“Impact of Medicaid Work Requirement on Healthcare Utilization and Healthcare Costs” Working paper
“A Campaign Worth a Thousand Words: The Value of Words in Crowdfunding Descriptions” with Anna Ruboyianes (California State University, San Bernardino) and Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) Working paper
“Impacts of Certificate of Need (CON) State Laws on Substance Use Treatment Facilities and Services” Working paper

Publications

Publication titles Journal
19. “Grading Policy, Email Nudges, and Grade Outcomes” with Michael Levinstein (Shippensburg University) Journal of Economic Education (2023)
18. “The Effect of Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs on County-Level Opioid Prescribing Practices and Spillovers” with Jane E. Ruseski (West Virginia University) Contemporary Economic Policy (2023)
17. “Exploring the Relationship between Nurse Practitioner Full Practice Authority, Nurse Practitioner Workforce Diversity, and Disparate Primary Care Access” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University), Kenrick Dwain Cato (Columbia University), Tina Sadarangani (New York University), Lusine Poghosyan (Columbia University), and Edward Timmons (West Virginia University) Policy, Politics, & Nursing Practice (2022)
16. “Must-access Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs and Retail Opioid Sales” with Collin Hodges (University of Central Arkansas) Contemporary Economic Policy (2022)
15. “Medicaid Expansion and Opioid Supply Policies to Address the Opioid Crisis” with Samantha Harrish (John Hopkins University) Drug and Alcohol Dependence Reports (2022)
14. “Shale Revolution, Oil and Gas Prices, and Drilling Activities in the United States” with Xiaoli Etienne (University of Idaho) and Bingxin Li (West Virginia University) Energy Economics (2022)
13. “Spatial Spillovers and the Productivity–compensation Gap in the United States” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) and Juan Tomas Sayago-Gomez (Universidad Icesi) The Annals of Regional Science (2022)
12. “Natural Disasters and Labor Migration: Evidence from Nepal’s Earthquake” with Subuna Basnet (University of Essex) and Jayash Paudel (University of Oklahoma) World Development (2022)
11. “Productivity Spillovers and the Productivity–compensation Gap” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) Spatial Economic Analysis (2022)
10. “The Fracking Boom and Crime Rates in the Rural American States: Some Critical Insights” with Kazi Sohag (Ural Federal University) The Extractive Industries and Society (2021)
9. “The Impact of Economic Freedom on Startups” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) Journal of Regional Analysis & Policy (2021)
8. “The Political Economy of Vermont’s Abortion Bill” with Elham Erfanian (Ohio University) and Alexandre Scarcioffolo (Georgia College & State University) Applied Economics Letters (2021)
7. “Does Scope of Practice Affect Mobility of Nurse Practitioners Serving Medicare Beneficiaries” with Alicia Plemmons (West Virginia University) Journal of Labor Research (2020)
6. “Quantifying the Announcement Effects in the US Lumber Futures Market” with Xiaoli Etienne (University of Idaho) and Zarina Ismailova (PNC Bank) Journal of Forest Economics (2020)
5. “The Political Economy of Vermont’s Anti-fracking Movement” with Josh Hall (West Virginia University) and Alexandre Scarcioffolo (Georgia College & State University) Journal of Public Finance and Public Choice (2021)
4. “Replication of a Research Claim from Bersani and Doherty (2013), from Criminology (2020)” with Eric L. Sevigny (Georgia State University) Center for Open Science, Systematizing Confidence in Open Research and Evidence (2020)
3. “Federal Regulations and US Energy Sector Output” with Josh Hall (West Virginia University) Oil, Gas, Energy Quarterly (2019)
2. “Electricity Consumption and Economic Growth: Empirical Evidence from a Resource-rich Landlocked Economy” with Rabindra Nepal (University of Tasmania) and Kishor Sharma (Charles Darwin University) International Journal of Global Energy Issues (2018)
1. “Possible Decision Rules to Allocate Quotas and Reservations to Ensure Equity for Nepalese Poor” with Nabraj Lama Economic Journal of Development Issues (2016)

item.title: Teachings
item.description:
CHAT GPT response based on my Fall 2022 teaching evaluation

“This text consists of multiple comments made by students regarding their experience with Professor Shishir Shakya, who teaches economics. The students have a mixed response to the course and the professor. Students find him friendly, personable, enthusiastic, and effective in teaching the material. Many students praise his ability to easily connect with students, make the course fun, and keep students engaged. While others find him difficult to understand and some of his assignments are confusing. Some students also feel that the online component of the course is challenging and the content from the textbook is different from what was taught in the class. Despite this, many students appreciate the practical and real-life examples used by the professor and find him to be a good teacher who is approachable and helpful. Overall, the students have a positive experience with Professor Shakya.”

Assistant Professor, Shippensburg University of Pennsylvania

  • ECO 393: Economic Analysis of Big Data Spring 2023
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Spring 2023
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Winter 2022
  • ECO 113: Principles of Economics Fall 2022
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Summer B 2022
  • ECO 393: Regional Economics Spring 2022
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Spring 2022
  • ECO 101: Principles of Microeconomics Winter 2021
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Fall 2021
  • ECO 113: Principles of Economics Fall 2021
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Summer B 2021
  • ECO 393: Economic Analysis of Big Data Spring 2021
  • ECO 101: Principles of Macroeconomics Spring 2021
  • ECO 113: Principles of Economics Winter 2020
  • ECO 113: Principles of Economics Fall 2020

Fall 2022

Median scores are out of a maximum possible score of 6. Princ Econ Princ Econ Princ Econ
Sections ECO113-01 ECO113-02 ECO113-03
1. The professor is willing to answer questions and assist students upon request. 5 6 6
2. The professor uses examples and practical applications in class which aid in my understanding of the material. 5 6 6
3. The professor encourages students to analyze, interpret and apply concepts. 5 6 5
4. The professor provides feedback on exams and assignments. 4 5 4
5. The course requirements, including grading system, were explained at the beginning of the semester. 5.5 6 6
6. The professor was effective teaching this course. 5 6 6

8. I believe the student ratings of faculty/course are used for course improvement. 4 6 6

Selected Student Comments Shippensburg University Fall 2022

“He uses realâlife examples to incorporate recent events relating to economics.”

“Professor Shakya is very nice, but a little hard to understand, he goes on long tangents that you can get lost in.”

“I feel that Professor Shishir Shakya is able to easily get along and connect with students. He is able to provide positive feedback and always has an example to try to explain a difficult concept. he goes back and forth drawing on the board and lecturing through slides which is a good mix.”

“Professor Shakya is a bright light at Ship. It was a shame how few gave him the attention deserved. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience he facilitated.”

“We buy a 100 dollar program and are told that we shouldnât read the book and instead let our intuition guide us. Yet some of the assingments we have require us to read the book.”

“Professor Shakya was very enthusiastic and enjoys teaching economics. He also offers a lot of opportunities for credit.”

“The professor made the course fun and I enjoyed coming into class”

“He makes sure to keep students engaged and is very friendly.”

“Very engaging and makes sure everyone understands the information before moving onto different material. Teaches at both a slow and fast pace.”

“it was online for the whole thing, so I slacked off and barely went to classes. Classes were waste of time. I like slacking off tho!”

“Our online textbook was all the material that we had to work through all semester. We were given a good amount of time to complete the chapter within a week.”

“Professor Shakya’s lessons were always so exceptionally vibrant. I had a blast watching his presentations and complementary materials.”

“I think that it would be helpful if the information on the assignments was taught in class. I was often confused because he wasn’t teaching me what I needed to know for the assignments I had to complete.”

“I would change the TuWTh schedule. I understand that this is a 4 credit class but the 3 days in a row can be a lot.”

“I would change how some of the questions for the online quiz and hw assignments are hard to understand and calculate; otherwise, I wouldn’t change much. The assignments are very lengthy and take a while to complete.”

“I was incredibly disappointed with my classes’ (not specfic to Shakya’s) reliance on McGraw Hill software. It seemed at times hardly taken into account, and other times required razorâsharp scrutiny to understand the topics.”

“Thank you for making me laugh when I needed it”

“Very upfront, funny and easy learning teacher very much enjoyed walking into the class every morning”

“This class was a waste!”

“I really thought this class was well run and everything went smoothly.”

“He goes over course material very thorough and helps the students to succeed”

“This was a nice class. it was not to stressful and I was able to keep up with assignments easily”

“I just wish that i understood the material more then just doing a slew of 30 different assignments and teaching myself how to do them.”

“The professor was very kind to me and did a great job teaching the course in my opinion. I had a great time in this class and Professor Shakya is always willing to answer and elaborate on questions, as well as being extremely flexible with students.”

“He makes sure everyone understands something before moving on to another topic overall the course is very good I can’t complain about anything”

“enjoyed the way the professor taught class, was really thorough with explanations”

“Professor Shakya is one of the most unique snd fun professors I have ever had.”

“Dr. Shakya was great at providing us with examples to help us understand the material in a practical and realistic way.”

“The online work can be very difficult when it doesn’t pertain to anything spoken of in class.”

“The SmartBook content often differed from what was taught in the classes, so it did feel like I was learning things in class and then also teaching myself different content outside of class.”

“Professor has asked for feedback, then improved his teaching style upon request.”

“I really enjoyed his personable attitude, I’m just not good at ecomonics”

“Dr. Shakya was overall and amazing professor, he connected nicely with me and my peers in order to make the class engaging. He took the time to learn our names, and was able to cater his lessons to the interests of the class.”

“Shishir was a great professor, and managed to make a stressful class easier and enjoyable”

“Although this class was not one of the most interesting subjects that I’ve had for the fall semester, I thought that my professor brought energy to the classroom and taught the various economics terms well enough for me to understand.”

“Dr. Shakya’s class is informative and allows the student to be successful. We are given a good amount of time to do all the assignments for the given chapter, and he helps quickly when you have questions.”

“Professor Shishir Shakya felt more like a friend than a professor. He made sure class was fun, but also made sure everything was learned in depth.”

“I got to get realâlife application of the class”

“Shishir was always enjoyable, and seemed to genuinely enjoy teaching the subject”

“Professor is funny and gets everyone involved, made a very safe learning environment for the students.”

“I would say the most positive aspect of this course was the overall personality and positive attitude of my professor who seemed like he truly cared about helping each student be more happy and understand the material.”

“Professor Shakya is an easy professor to be engaged with due his passion for his subject and active teaching style. There’s a lot of interaction between the students and professor which makes the class very inclusive and close.”

“Heâs always positive and upbeat, heâs personable too. I always enjoy going to to his class.”

“He is a lot of fun and he is really good at explaining and describing the content. Also, he interacts with all students on a personal level which is really nice.”

“his examples used throughout the class”

“I wouldnât change anything about the course”

“I am slightly interested in the material of this course, but I wish that we would have approached the topic of regional economics in other ways besides using RStudio. I don’t have much coding experience, so it was more difficult for me compared to other students to complete assignments in RStudio even though I conceptually understood what Professor Shakya discussed in class.”

“Fun and interesting applied material.”

“Even though this class has been difficult for me, Professor Shakya is a friendly, helpful, flexible professor. He will cover concepts more than once for students if needed, takes time in class to ensure that everyone is on the same page (if not, he will take time to help us in class) and always makes it a point to ask how we are doing and how comfortable we feel with the material. He also uses realâworld scenarios, data, and software to show us how to analyze regional economic situations. In addition, Professor Shakya set a casual precedence for the course, so I’ve felt more comfortable participating in class and asking for help because his “lectures” felt more like backâandâforth conversations that revolved around what my classmates and I wanted to discuss (within the course topic) and where we wanted more clarification.”

“Professor Shakya was extremely helpful and understanding throughout the course. I found it most positive that he would make sure his students understood the information he was teaching.”

“Dr. Shakya created an efficient way to teach class with everyone on the same page.”

“I would have liked to discuss regional economic issues in ways other than through RStudio. While this system has helped me to more efficiently gather useful data, I would also like to go through the process of devising solutions to regional economic issues. For example, having discussions about current regional economic issues and discussing ways in which economists could find costâefficient solutions during some classes would be interesting.”

“We spent a lot of time learning to code in R. I think it would have been beneficial to take a data science course before this class, as a prerequisite. It would have helped to move the class at a quicker pace.”

“Overall, I enjoyed my time in Professor Shakyaâs course. He was very personable and helped me to understand the bigger picture of economics regionally. I wish I would have taken this course before taking research and analysis with Dr. Freddy Siahaan. It would have prepared me to better understand the data I was analyzing. I know it was Professor Shakyaâs first time teaching this course and I believe he will continue to improve the course material for future Ship students.”

Selected Student Comments Shippensburg University Fall 2021

“The energy that Shishir had while teaching helped to keep his class engaged, and his humor helped to lighten the mood for an otherwise stressful subject.”

“How upfront and set the schedule was, so I always knew what was due and when.”

“Consistency in material each week and the willingness to work with students. Very modern class.”

“He greatly appreciates student feedback and wants everyone to succeed. You know what to expect each week as far as assignments and quizzes, that helps me to do well because I can effectively plan my week.”

“Managerial Economics is already a difficult course, however, Professor Shakya gave us the tools to make it easier for us to understand it.”

“Shishir teaches this course in a way that makes the material easier to understand, he uses many examples and relates the material to the real world.”

“Professor Shakya is truly dedicated to the success of all of his students. He developed a unique weekly grading system in which you could see your course grade as the weeks continue to go. On top of that, he also does not want to see any of his students fail, so he has methods he uses to try to motivate his students to bring up their grade. He is very knowledgeable within his field, which really helps as he can find things that can help us understand a particular concept better. Finally, he always makes sure that if the lecture’s content is heavy that he will give us a five minute break to break up the amount of things he is teaching at once”

“He is by far my favorite teacher here ever. I really liked what I was learning and how he taught me. He has to be the most dedicated techer I have met here and I am completely grateful.”

“Although I don’t have much interest in economics in general, this class managed to hold my attention. The professor did an excellent job this semester.”

“The professor was very flexible in teaching his class. Not only did that flexibility help in his class, it also helped for outside courses too. Teaching in this manner helped me achieve the highest grade possible.”

“I really enjoyed Shishir’s class. He did a great job at wanting you to succeed and teaching the class a tough subject.”

“He is very knowledgeable about the course matter and is willing to help anyone struggling inside or outside of class.”

“The most positive aspect of this course would be that Professor Shakya was willing to listen to his students and use the feedback that he received to better the course and our overall experience.”

“The professor was very passionate about what he was teaching, and personable with the students. It made coming to class more enjoyable. The prof also gave students the opportunity to earn many points, which not a lot of professors do.”

“The most positive aspect of this course was that Professor Shishir was very personable and brought energy to the classroom.”

“Mr. Shishir took time to go over everything we were struggling on and he understands when we are all worn out and need a break”

“I like the overall setup of the course. It was straightforward and was organized well. There were no surprise grades and it was all pretty fair. As a student you knew what was expected and that is something I enjoy. [Other] professors can be negligent on notifying about random assignment but since this was the same structure every week, it was easy to prepare for and manage the time to work on the class.”

“I really enjoyed Professor Shakya and think is class will really aid me in the future. I especially enjoyed his investment unit at the end of the class; I feel as if I can really implement it in the future.”

“Shishir made a very scary course tolerable and allowed me, who is terrible at math, to understand complex math”

“Overall, Shakya, or Shishir as he wants us to refer to him as, is a very caring and smart professor. He’s young, which helps him relate to his students more, and willing to receive feedback, given that he usually asks us for it all of the time. He understands that ECO 280 is a pretty heavy course for those not majoring in economics, so he makes sure to give his student’s enough resources to get through it.”

“I only agree that the subject of the course interests me because of this professor. I had no interest or even a like of economics before taking this class, and Professor Shakya changed that. I never really understood economics and so it frustrated me more than anything else. But after this course I understand economics and have an interest in it. Still no love for the subject, but now a healthy interest.”

“He did a very good job teaching us the subjects that were brought up on the syllabus. My favorite part of the class was at the end when he talked about investing and the stock market.”

“Best Prof I have had since my 2 years Iâve been going to ship, cares about his students and wants them to do well in his class. Very good at teaching and loved getting to know him.”

“He is very laid back and gave us breaks when we seemed to get overwhelmed with other school work. I appreciated that so much. He was very nice as you advanced through the class.”

“He made sure to stop and make sure we understood the work and how to do it on our own.”

“Professor Shakya was always willing to help students in class if they had any questions about the content in front of them. He also allowed students to ask questions one on one directly after class. He frequently asked if students needed any clarification and if they were able to understand the content.”

“Anytime I had a question, Dr. Shakya was always prompt to answer it. Also, while assignments had hard deadlines, Dr. Shakya was merciful and gave people wiggle room if they had missed the date for legitimate reasons.”

“He taught this class very well especially considering I didnât think I would understand the material well but I ended up doing better than I thought. He explains the material throughly and in an easy way to understand. Although I wish there was more feedback on assignments or that he wouldâve went over more missed questions on the homeworkâs or quizzes.”

“Great teaching and responding to emails, he cares about you a lot and will take time out of class to help you.”

“Professor Shakya is knowledgeable and passionate about his subject. He is able to teach in a manner that works for most students and is willing to adapt for oneâonâone instruction as needed. An enjoyable professor who is fair, reasonable, and an excellent instructor.”

“Donât ever wanna lose contact with this prof, amazing teacher.”

“Professor Shakya was kind to the students and did his best to engage them in the course content. He allowed us to ask him questions on specific topics of interest in the classroom so that we were able to learn more. He also switched up the methods of displaying the content, from writing on the blackboard to a slideshow to showing videos, the diversity in the display of content kept it interesting.”

“He is a very highâenergy professor and loves to teach students and it is very prevalent in the way the class is run. He gave us realâworld examples that we can apply to our life.”

“The professor is very effective in giving and helping us retain information, along with adding new topics.”

“He explained the material throughly. He was always willing to help if we had any questions. “I would like to see Professor Shakya stay at Shippensburg. It is important to have younger professors who understand a bit more about technology and who are able to have a fresh perspective and energy.”

“I’m an economics major and had to take this course as a requirement. I thought Professor Shakya did a great job in helping me understand the content. He was always willing to answer questions and was very fun. You can tell that he cares and wants us to succeed.”

“It shed some light on the complexity of economic issues our country and the world struggles to balance. I felt that it was just about the right amount of hardness for an introductory course. You had to pay attention but I didn’t feel overloaded by the course.”

“He made the class fun and interesting. He also was kind when understanding we are busy with other classes. Shows real world problems.”

“The best aspect of this course is Dr. Shakya showing realâworld examples of macroeconomic concepts in practice. It has aided my understanding of the concepts and their importance.”

“The grading system was one of the best aspects. Every assignment would be graded quickly and updated in D2L so I always knew what my grade was. The assignments directly told you what the correct answer was even if you got it incorrect.”

“He is a great teacher, has such a nice positive attitude that makes you want to go to class. The only thing I feel like I disliked about the course is that it is hard to keep on track because he does not clarify due dates or he is very disorganized with this course.”

“Dr. Shakya tried his best to appease the class although in his shoes I can understand it can be difficult to strive too far from the original structure. He always remained positive and provided ample opportunities for feedback.”

“This course was effective in teaching me how to analyze big data and understand the bigger concepts. I liked how we learned about different perspectives of data and how the affect one another.”
